DOC.HEAD: Family Slaying Suspects Leave Credit Card Trail
DOC.TEXT: Credit and bank cards belonging to a family of four found slain last week were used to buy sneakers, underwear, electronic equipment and diamonds the day after the killings, police said Sunday. Descriptions and composite drawings of the buyers were circulated over the weekend by police in the hope that someone would recognize them. Six purchases totaling $1,334 were made Dec. 23, the day the bodies of Warren Harris, 39, Dolores Harris, 41, and their two children, ages 11 and 15, were found in their suburban Ithaca home, police said. The four had been bound, shot in the back of the head and their bodies set on fire the night before. Police believe the cards are being used by a man and a woman, said Capt. Carl Shaver of the state police Bureau of Criminal Investigation. The partly charred bodies were discovered when a neighbor heard a smoke alarm. Police said there was no sign of a forced entry, and neighbors speculated the friendly family may have opened their door to people saying they had car trouble. The Harrises lived in Ellis Hollow, an affluent section of this rural town about five miles from Ithaca in western New York state.
